modules.title: Financial Foundations
modules.description: Build a strong foundation in personal finance and understand the basics of money management before diving into investing.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Something you own that has value and can generate income or appreciate over time.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a fruit tree in your backyard - it's yours, it grows, and gives you fruit (income) every season.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Money you owe to others, like loans or credit card debt.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like borrowing your neighbor's lawn mower - you need to return it (pay it back), and maybe with a favor (interest).

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Your total assets minus your total liabilities - essentially what you'd have if you sold everything and paid off all debts.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: If you sold all your belongings at a garage sale and paid off all your IOUs, what's left in your pocket is your net worth.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Earning interest on your interest - your money grows exponentially over time.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a snowball rolling down a hill - it starts small but picks up more snow (interest) as it rolls, getting bigger and bigger.

modules.title: Market Basics
modules.description: Understand how stock markets work, who the key players are, and how trading happens.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A marketplace where buyers and sellers trade stocks of publicly listed companies.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a farmer's market, but instead of vegetables, people buy and sell tiny pieces of companies (stocks).

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A unit of ownership in a company. When you buy a stock, you own a small piece of that company.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like owning a slice of pizza from a whole pizza - you own that slice, and if the pizza becomes more valuable, so does your slice.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A market condition where stock prices are rising or expected to rise.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a bull charging forward with its horns up - everything is moving upward with optimism.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A market condition where stock prices are falling or expected to fall by 20% or more.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a bear swiping downward with its paw - prices are being pushed down, and investors are cautious.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: When a private company offers its shares to the public for the first time.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a local bakery opening its doors to investors - anyone can now buy a piece of the bakery and share in its profits.

modules.title: Trading vs. Investing
modules.description: Learn the key differences between short-term trading and long-term investing strategies.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Buying and selling stocks within the same day to profit from short-term price movements.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like flipping concert tickets - you buy them in the morning and sell them by evening for a quick profit.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Buying stocks with the intention of holding them for years to benefit from company growth.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like planting an oak tree - you wait patiently for years, and eventually, it becomes strong and valuable.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A portion of a company's profits paid out to shareholders, usually quarterly.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like getting a share of the pizza shop's profits every few months just for being a part-owner.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: The profit you make when you sell a stock for more than you paid for it.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like buying a vintage toy for ‚Çπ100 and selling it years later for ‚Çπ500 - the ‚Çπ400 difference is your capital gain.

modules.title: Fundamental Analysis
modules.description: Evaluate a company's financial health and intrinsic value to make informed investment decisions.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A valuation metric that compares a company's stock price to its earnings per share.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like comparing the price of a house to its yearly rental income - it tells you if you're paying too much or getting a good deal.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: The total value of a company's outstanding shares (stock price √ó number of shares).
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like the total value of all slices of pizza if you were to sell the entire pizza shop.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: The portion of a company's profit allocated to each outstanding share of stock.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: If a pizza shop makes ‚Çπ1000 profit and has 100 slices (shares), each slice earns ‚Çπ10 - that's the EPS.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A financial statement showing a company's assets, liabilities, and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a snapshot of your bank account, debts, and belongings - it shows your financial position right now.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Revenue is total income, while profit is what's left after subtracting all expenses.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Revenue is all the money your lemonade stand makes; profit is what you keep after paying for lemons, sugar, and cups.

modules.title: Technical Analysis
modules.description: Use charts, patterns, and indicators to predict future price movements based on historical data.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A chart that shows the open, high, low, and close prices of a stock for a specific time period.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a weather report showing the day's temperature range - the candle shows the stock's price range for the day.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A price level where a stock tends to stop falling and bounce back up.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a trampoline - the stock price hits this level and bounces back up instead of falling further.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: A price level where a stock tends to stop rising and pull back down.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a ceiling - the stock price hits this level and can't break through, so it falls back down.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: The average price of a stock over a specific number of days, used to smooth out price fluctuations.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like tracking your average daily steps over a month - it smooths out the ups and downs to show the overall trend.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: The number of shares traded during a specific time period.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like the number of people at a concert - high volume means lots of activity and interest.

modules.title: Risk Management
modules.description: Protect your capital and minimize losses through smart portfolio management and risk mitigation strategies.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: Spreading your investments across different assets to reduce risk.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like not putting all your eggs in one basket - if one basket drops, you still have eggs in other baskets.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: An order to automatically sell a stock when it reaches a certain price to limit your losses.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like setting a safety net - if the stock falls too far, it automatically sells to prevent bigger losses.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: The potential profit compared to the potential loss of an investment.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like betting ‚Çπ10 to potentially win ‚Çπ30 - you're risking ‚Çπ10 for a ‚Çπ30 reward (3:1 ratio).

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: How you divide your money among different types of investments (stocks, bonds, cash, etc.).
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like dividing your monthly budget - 50% for groceries, 30% for rent, 20% for savings.

keyTerms.simpleDefinition: How much and how quickly a stock's price changes.
keyTerms.realWorldAnalogy: Like a roller coaster - high volatility means big ups and downs, low volatility is a smooth, steady ride.
